Posts.Content: Thank you for the replies.. I visited my onc for a checkup and he told me that even if I am in menopause ( one period six months ago!) he probably would not switch me over to Arimidex because he has seen too many women with joint and muscle pain who then had to be switched back to tamoxifen. Something the drug magazine ads won't tell you... I do feel better knowing that I'm not the only one with achiness in my breast and muscle pain. I think I have to find the perfect bra, maybe that would help.. Donna Macungie, PA See my info above
Posts.Title: Muscle Pain almost two years after treatment

Posts.Content: After having every scan known to mankind, (PET, Bone CT), I'm "clear" my upper back pain remains undiagnosed. It appears to be muscular in nature. The strange thing is, my neighbor, who was also treated with chemo and radiation, also has back pain. One onc. thinks it could be the tamoxifen, another says maybe it's the radiation, the radiologist says it's the chemo! Anyone else experience this? Also, anyone still having breast pain at the surgery/radiation site after treatment? Thanks Donna DX 10/03 (Happy anniversary to me!) 3 lumpectomy, 4A/C 34 Rad.
Posts.Title: Muscle Pain almost two years after treatment

Posts.Title: Muscle Pain almost two years after treatment

Posts.Content: I forgot to add, went to PT for 4 months, although I don't think it was the right kind- more like weight training. A doctor (physical medicine & rehab) I saw last week said it probably hurt more than helped. He gave me a cortisone shot, which did nothing, and prescribed stretching. I know this seems minor in comparison to what other people are going through, but having constant tightness and aching is a drag. Massage seems to help the most, I make my husband work that part of my back every night! Think I'm going to buy one of those back massage thingies!! Donna Age 44 DX 10/03 Invasive ductal- 1cm- Lymph node negative- Lumpectomy ER PR + 4 A/C + Radiation Tamoxifen [/img]

Posts.Title: Muscle Pain almost two years after treatment

Posts.Content: I too am 44 and got my period back one time 15 months after starting chemo. A blood test a few months ago indicated I was not in menopause. They are currently doing clinical trials to determine whether it would benefit premenopausal women more to switch them to Arimidex or Femara after chemically supressing or surgically removing ovaries. For more info on this, go to the breastcancer.org site, it is excellent and gives you updates on everything. Since I have only had one period, my onc is taking a "wait and see" approach, that is, I may go into menopause and be able to switch to the newer meds. In any event, he believes that ovarian supression would be of minimal benefit to me, as long as I am on Tamoxifen. This was confirmed by a speciality breast oncologist at the University of PA. In other words, they will know more about whether to force us into menopause and put us on aromitase inhibitors when these studies come back!
Posts.Title: ovary supression w/ tamoxifen

Posts.Content: I know that the waiting is terrible, but keep in mind that most lumps are benign. If you're only 32, were you nursing over the last few years? I used to have lumps and fluid coming out of the nipple for up to two years after I stopped... Getting it checked out is a good thing. Maybe going to a breast surgeon just to be sure is a good idea even if your PCP says "it's nothing". Take it one step at a time, and know that if you need us we're here. I have cysty breasts too, and you have to realize that cysts do NOT turn cancerous.. I'll be praying for you. Donna Age 44 Pennsylvania
Posts.Title: questions about breast cancer, worried please help

Posts.Content: Not sure this is the same thing, but 4-5months after radiation, I experienced shortness of breath when exercising, and I considered myself fairly active. I think it can be fluid retention, too, from the surgical trauma, or just some type of inflammation. ( that's what my radiologist thought) I experienced it again recently, and the doctors are scratching their heads. Heart tests and chest X-rays show nothing. Think about the chemo and surgery and what it can do to a body. I really think there needs to be more in the way of follow-up for survivors! Donna Age 44 Dx'd 10/03 1cm, er/pr pos. Stage 1 3 lumpectomies, 4 AC, rad
Posts.Title: Shortness of breath
